docs.title: 1. Vector Algebra
docs.text:
Given two vectors in 3D space: \(\vec{a} = [2, 1, -3]\) and \(\vec{b} = [4, -2, 1]\). Calculate:

a) The magnitude of each vector. b) The dot product \(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}\). c) The cross product \(\vec{a} \times \vec{b}\). d) The angle between vectors \(\vec{a}\) and \(\vec{b}\).

docs.title: 2. Solving Systems of Equations
docs.text: Find the values of \(x\) and \(y\) that satisfy both equations: \(2x + 3y = 12\) and \(x - y = 1\).

docs.title: 3. Proportionality (Scaling)
docs.text: Consider the Universal Law of Gravitation: \(F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}\), where \(F\) is the gravitational force between two masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\), \(r\) is the distance between their centers, and \(G\) is the gravitational constant. Determine the factor by which the force \(F\) changes if the distance \(r\) is doubled and both masses (\(m_1\) and \(m_2\)) are halved.

docs.title: 4. Rearranging Formulas
docs.text: The formula for the period of a simple pendulum is \(T = 2\pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{g}}\) Rearrange the equation give formula for \(g\) (acceleration due to gravity).

docs.title: 5. Trigonometry
docs.text: A vector \(\vec{A}\) has a magnitude of \(15\) and makes an angle of \(\theta = 60^\circ\) with the horizontal axis. Calculate its horizontal and vertical components.

docs.title: 6. Function Analysis
docs.text: Consider the function \(f(x) = 3x^2 - 12x + 7\). Identify any local maxima or minima.

docs.title: 7. Logic & Series
docs.text: A bicycle is 10 meters from a wall and moves towards it at a constant speed of \(1\text{ m/s}\). A fly starts from the bicycle's front wheel and flies towards the wall at \(2\text{ m/s}\). When it hits the wall, it instantly turns back and flies to the bicycle, and so on. What is the total distance the fly travels before being crushed?

docs.title: 8. Definite Integrals
docs.text: Calculate the area under the curve of the function \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) from \(x=0\) to \(x=\pi\).

docs.title: 9. Optimalization Problem
docs.text: A rectangle is under the curve \(y = 3 - x^2\) in the first quadrant. What are the dimensions of the rectangle with the maximum area?

docs.title: 10. Infinite Series in 2D
docs.text: Determine the final position of an ant that starts at the origin and moves according to the following pattern: 1 m east, 1/2 m north, 1/3 m west, 1/4 m south, 1/5 m east, and so on.

docs.title: 1. Projectile Motion Analysis
docs.text:
A projectile is fired from the ground with an initial velocity of \(100 \text{ m/s}\) at an angle of \(37^\circ\) above the horizontal. Calculate:

a) The maximum height reached. b) The total time of flight. c) The horizontal range of the projectile.

docs.title: 2. Range Optimization
docs.text: For projectile motion, show analytically that the maximum range for a given initial velocity is achieved at a launch angle of \(45^\circ\).

docs.title: 3. Path Intersection
docs.text: Alice is moving along a path described by \(A(t) = (2+t, 8-3t)\) and Bob is moving along a path \(B(t) = (2t-1, 2t+2)\). Determine if their paths intersect. Will they collide at the same time?

docs.title: 4. 2D Collision Trajectories
docs.text: Two cannons are aimed at each other. The first cannon at \((0,0)\) fires a projectile with an initial velocity of \([100 \text{ m/s}, 80 \text{ m/s}]\). The second cannon at \((800 \text{ m}, 0)\) fires a projectile with a velocity of \([-100 \text{ m/s}, 80 \text{ m/s}]\). At what time \(t\) and at what point \((x,y)\) will they collide?

docs.title: 5. Relative Velocity (River Problem)
docs.text: A river flows east at \(2 \text{ m/s}\). A boat that can travel at \(5 \text{ m/s}\) in still water wants to go directly north across the river. In what direction (angle) should it head? How long will it take to cross the river if it's 200 meters wide?

docs.title: 6. Variable Velocity
docs.text: An object's velocity is given by \(v(t) = t^2 + 2t - 5\). If the object is at \(x=4\) at \(t=0\), what is its position at \(t=3\)?

docs.title: 7. Vertical Collision
docs.text: A stone is thrown vertically upward with a speed of \(20 \text{ m/s}\). A second stone is thrown vertically upward with a speed of \(30 \text{ m/s}\) exactly one second later. At what time and height do they collide?

docs.title: 8. Circular Motion
docs.text: Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a person standing on the Earth's equator. The Earth's radius is approximately 6378 km.

docs.title: 9. Momentum Comparison
docs.text: Which has greater momentum: a 2-gram fly flying at 10 m/s or a 60-gram tennis ball moving at 1 m/s?

docs.title: 10. Vector Calculus
docs.text: The position of an object is given by \(\vec{r}(t) = (3t^2)\hat{i} + (5t - 8t^2)\hat{j}\). Find the object's velocity and acceleration vectors as a function of time.

docs.title: 1. Gravitational Dependence
docs.text: A simple pendulum has a period of 4 seconds on Earth. What would its period be on the Moon, where the gravitational acceleration is about 1/6th of Earth's?

docs.title: 2. Inelastic Collision
docs.text: A 70 kg runner moving at \(3 \text{ m/s}\) jumps onto a 140 kg stationary cart. What is the final speed of the cart with the runner? Is kinetic energy conserved in this collision? Explain.

docs.title: 3. Simple Harmonic Motion
docs.text: A 10 kg mass is attached to a spring and oscillates according to the equation \(x(t) = 0.2 \cos(10\pi t)\) (in meters). What is the spring constant \(k\)? What is the total mechanical energy of the system?

docs.title: 4. Conservation of Energy
docs.text: A pendulum with a length of 1.0 meter is released from an initial angle of \(15^\circ\). What is the speed of the pendulum bob at the bottom of its swing?

docs.title: 5. Energy & Momentum Combination
docs.text: A 0.5 kg block slides down a frictionless track from a height of 3.0 m. At the bottom, it collides and sticks to a 1.5 kg block which is initially at rest. What is the speed of the combined mass just after the collision?

docs.title: 6. Horizontal Projectile
docs.text: A stone is thrown horizontally with a speed of \(20 \text{ m/s}\) from the top of a cliff that is 50 m high. How far from the base of the cliff does the stone land?

docs.title: 7. Dynamics with Friction
docs.text: A 5 kg block is placed on a 10 kg block. A horizontal force of 45 N is applied to the 10 kg block, and the 5 kg block is tied to the wall. The coefficient of kinetic friction between all moving surfaces is 0.2. Find the acceleration of the 10 kg block.

docs.title: 8. Pendulum Design
docs.text: What is the required length of a simple pendulum to have a period of exactly 1 second on Earth?

docs.title: 9. Kinematics Integration
docs.text: The velocity of an object is given by \(v(t) = 4t + 5\). Find the displacement \(x(t)\) and acceleration \(a(t)\), assuming \(x(0)=0\).

docs.title: 10. Energy Dissipation
docs.text: A tennis ball is dropped from a height of 2.0 m. After each bounce, it loses 30% of its mechanical energy. To what height does it rise after the second bounce?

docs.title: 1. Wave Properties
docs.text: A sound wave in air has a frequency of 440 Hz. If the speed of sound in air is 343 m/s, what is its wavelength? What is its wavelength in water, where the speed of sound is 1482 m/s?

docs.title: 2. String Harmonics
docs.text: A guitar string is 64 cm long and has a fundamental frequency (one antinode) of 330 Hz. What is the speed of the wave on this string?

docs.title: 3. Superposition Principle
docs.text: Two waves are described by the equations \(y_1(x, t) = A \sin(kx - \omega t)\) and \(y_2(x, t) = A \sin(kx + \omega t)\). What is the equation of the resulting standing wave? Identify the positions of the nodes.

docs.title: 4. Echo Ranging
docs.text: A person shouts towards a cliff and hears the echo 4.0 seconds later. How far away is the cliff? (Speed of sound in air is 343 m/s).

docs.title: 5. Doppler Effect (Light)
docs.text: A galaxy is receding from Earth at a speed of \(5 \times 10^6 \text{ m/s}\). It emits light with a wavelength of 486 nm (blue-green). What wavelength will be observed on Earth?

docs.title: 6. Wave Equation Analysis
docs.text:
A wave is described by the equation \(y(x,t) = 0.05 \sin(2\pi x - 50\pi t)\), where x and y are in meters and t is in seconds. Determine the wave's:

a) Amplitude b) Wavelength c) Frequency d) Speed

docs.title: 7. Phase Difference
docs.text: What is the phase difference in radians between two points on a wave that are separated by a distance of \(\lambda/3\)?

docs.title: 8. Standing Wave Modes
docs.text: A standing wave with four antinodes is produced on a string of length L = 80 cm. What is the wavelength of this wave?

docs.title: 9. Wave Equation Verification
docs.text:
Which of the following functions can describe a traveling wave? (Hint: check if it satisfies the wave equation \(\frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial x^2} = \frac{1}{v^2} \frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial t^2}\))

a) \(y(x,t) = A \cos(kx^2 - \omega t)\) b) \(y(x,t) = A(x-vt)^2\) c) \(y(x,t) = A \log(x+vt)\)

docs.title: 10. Resonance
docs.text: Determine the frequency of a standing wave with two antinodes on a guitar string, given the wave velocity is 1500 m/s and the string length is 1.0 m.

docs.title: 1. Coulomb's Law (2D)
docs.text: Four point charges of +1.0 C each are placed at the corners of a square with sides of 1.0 m. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the electric force on a charge of -2.0 C placed at the center of the square.

docs.title: 2. Electric Potential
docs.text: Point charges of +1C, -2C, +3C, and -4C are placed at the corners of a square with sides of 1.0 m (in order). Calculate the electric potential at the center of the square.

docs.title: 3. Magnetic Field of Charge
docs.text: An electron is moving in a circular path with a radius of \(r=10 \text{ cm}\) at a constant speed of \(v=10^6 \text{ m/s}\). Calculate the magnitude of the magnetic field it produces at the center of the circle.

docs.title: 4. Mass Spectrometry Principles
docs.text: A proton (charge \(+e\), mass \(m_p\)) and an alpha particle (charge \(+2e\), mass \(\approx 4m_p\)) enter a uniform magnetic field with the same velocity, perpendicular to the field lines. What is the ratio of the radii of their circular paths, \(r_p / r_\alpha\)?

docs.title: 5. Force Comparison
docs.text: Calculate the magnitude of the electric force and the gravitational force between an electron and a proton in a hydrogen atom (average distance \(r \approx 5.3 \times 10^{-11} \text{ m}\)). What is the ratio \(F_e/F_g\)?

docs.title: 6. Cyclotron Motion
docs.text: An electron is accelerated from rest through a potential difference of 5000 V. It then enters a region of uniform magnetic field B = 0.1 T, perpendicular to its velocity. What is the radius of the circular path it will follow?

docs.title: 7. Lorentz Force on Wire
docs.text:
A straight wire 2.0 m long carries a current of 10 A. It is placed in a uniform magnetic field of B = 0.5 T. Calculate the magnetic force on the wire if the angle between the wire and the magnetic field is:

a) \(90^\circ\) b) \(45^\circ\) c) \(0^\circ\)

docs.title: 8. Electrostatic Equilibrium
docs.text: Find the equilibrium position for a charge \(q_3 = +1\text{C}\) placed on the line between a charge \(q_1 = +4\text{C}\) and a charge \(q_2 = +9\text{C}\) which are separated by a distance of 2 m.

docs.title: 9. Vector Lorentz Force
docs.text: A proton moves with a velocity \(\vec{v} = (2\hat{i} - 4\hat{j} + \hat{k}) \text{ m/s}\) in a region where the magnetic field is \(\vec{B} = (\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} - \hat{k}) \text{ T}\). What is the magnitude of the magnetic force this charge experiences?

docs.title: 10. Field Levitation
docs.text: What electric field strength is required to make a proton levitate against Earth's gravity at the level of the Earth's surface? (Mass of proton \(m_p \approx 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\), charge of proton \(e \approx 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}\), gravitational acceleration \(g \approx 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\)).

docs.title: 1. Refraction (Snell's Law)
docs.text: A light ray travels from air (n=1.00) into glass (n=1.50). If the angle of incidence is \(30^\circ\), what is the angle of refraction?

docs.title: 2. Lorentz Force
docs.text: A charged particle with charge \(q = 2 \times 10^{-19}\) C and mass \(m = 4 \times 10^{-27}\) kg enters a magnetic field of \(B = 0.5\) T at a speed of \(v = 10^6\) m/s perpendicular to the field. What is the magnitude of the Lorentz force acting on the particle?

docs.title: 3. Photon Energy
docs.text: The human eye is most sensitive to light with a wavelength of about 550 nm (in vacuum). What is the frequency of this light? What is its energy in electron-volts (eV)?

docs.title: 4. EM Wave Analysis
docs.text: An electromagnetic wave has its electric field component described by \(E_y(x,t) = 100 \sin(10^7 x - \omega t) \text{ V/m}\). What is the direction of propagation? What is the wavelength \(\lambda\)? What is the angular frequency \(\omega\)? What is the equation for the magnetic field component?

docs.title: 5. Ampere's Law Application
docs.text: Two long, parallel wires are 10 cm apart and carry currents of 5 A in opposite directions. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at a point midway between the wires.

docs.title: 6. Transformer Ratio
docs.text: A transformer is used to step down the voltage from 120 V AC to 9.0 V AC. If the primary coil has 400 turns, how many turns must the secondary coil have?

docs.title: 7. Magnetic Torque
docs.text: A rectangular loop of wire with dimensions 10 cm by 5 cm carries a current of 2 A. A uniform magnetic field of B = 0.3 T is applied parallel to the plane of the loop. What is the magnitude of the magnetic torque on the loop?

docs.title: 8. Speed of Light in Media
docs.text: What is the speed of light in a diamond, which has an index of refraction n = 2.42?

docs.title: 9. EM Spectrum
docs.text: List the following types of electromagnetic radiation in order of increasing energy per photon: Infrared, Ultraviolet, Microwaves, X-rays, Radio waves, Gamma rays.

docs.title: 10. Capacitor Energy Storage
docs.text: A parallel-plate capacitor with plate area 0.1 m² and plate separation 1 mm is connected to a 12 V battery. Calculate the capacitance of the capacitor and the energy stored in it.

docs.title: 1. Series Circuit Analysis
docs.text:
Three resistors, \(R_1=15\,Ω\), \(R_2=30\,Ω\), and \(R_3=50\,Ω\), are connected in series to a 12 V battery.

a) Draw the circuit diagram. b) Calculate the total equivalent resistance. c) Calculate the current flowing from the battery.

docs.title: 2. Parallel Circuit Analysis
docs.text:
The same three resistors (\(R_1=15\,Ω\), \(R_2=30\,Ω\), \(R_3=50\,Ω\)) are now connected in parallel to the 12 V battery.

a) Draw the circuit diagram. b) Calculate the total equivalent resistance. c) Calculate the current flowing through each resistor. d) Calculate the total current flowing from the battery.

docs.title: 3. Mixed Circuit
docs.text: A resistor \(R_1=10\,Ω\) is connected in series with a parallel combination of two other resistors, \(R_2=20\,Ω\) and \(R_3=20\,Ω\). The entire circuit is connected to a 6 V source. What is the total current drawn from the source?

docs.title: 4. Kirchhoff's Laws
docs.text: Using Kirchhoff's laws, find the currents \(I_1, I_2, I_3\) in a circuit with two loops. Loop 1 (left): a 10V battery and a \(2\Omega\) resistor, shared branch in the middle. Loop 2 (right): a 5V battery and a \(3\Omega\) resistor. The shared branch has a \(5\Omega\) resistor. Assume currents are flowing out of the positive terminals.

docs.title: 5. Current Definition
docs.text: A lightning bolt transfers a charge of 30 Coulombs to the ground in a time of 2 milliseconds. What is the average current of the lightning bolt?

docs.title: 6. Symmetry in Circuits
docs.text: A cube is constructed from 12 identical resistors, each with resistance R. What is the equivalent resistance between two opposite corners of the cube?

docs.title: 7. Power & Energy
docs.text: What is the power dissipated by a \(100\,Ω\) resistor when a voltage of 50 V is applied across it? How much energy is consumed in 5 minutes?

docs.title: 8. Multi-Source Circuit
docs.text: For a circuit consisting of a 2V battery and a 1-ohm resistor in the left loop, and a 1V battery and a 3-ohm resistor in the right loop, with a 2-ohm resistor in the middle branch, calculate all currents.

docs.title: 9. Delta Connection
docs.text: Find the equivalent resistance of a circuit where three \(10\,Ω\) resistors are connected to form a triangle (delta connection). What is the resistance between any two vertices?

docs.title: 10. Resistor Logic Puzzle
docs.text: You have an supply of \(1\,Ω\) resistors. How can you combine them to create an equivalent resistance of \(2.5\,Ω\)? Draw the diagram.

docs.title: 1. Capacitors in Parallel
docs.text: Two capacitors, \(C_1=4\,μ\text{F}\) and \(C_2=6\,μ\text{F}\), are connected in parallel to a 10 V battery. What is the total charge stored on the capacitors? What is the total energy stored?

docs.title: 2. Capacitors in Series
docs.text: The same two capacitors (\(C_1=4\,μ\text{F}\) and \(C_2=6\,μ\text{F}\)) are now connected in series to the 10 V battery. What is the charge on each capacitor and the voltage across each capacitor?

docs.title: 3. RLC Impedance
docs.text: A series RLC circuit has \(R=20\,Ω\), \(L=10 \text{ mH}\), and \(C=50\,μ\text{F}\). It is connected to an AC source with a frequency of 100 Hz. a) Calculate the inductive reactance (\(X_L\)). b) Calculate the capacitive reactance (\(X_C\)). c) Calculate the total impedance (Z) of the circuit.

docs.title: 4. Resonance
docs.text: For the RLC circuit in the previous problem, what is the resonant frequency? What would the impedance of the circuit be at resonance?

docs.title: 5. Transformer Currents
docs.text: A transformer has a primary coil with 1000 turns and a secondary coil with 200 turns. If the primary voltage is 120 V (AC), what is the secondary voltage? If the current in the secondary is 3 A, what is the current in the primary (assuming an ideal transformer)?

docs.title: 6. AC Voltage Equation
docs.text: The current in an AC circuit is given by \(I(t) = 2 \sin(120π t)\). If the circuit consists of a single \(50\,Ω\) resistor, what is the equation for the voltage \(V(t)\) across it?

docs.title: 7. RC Decay
docs.text: A 5 F capacitor is connected to a DC voltage source. A graph of current vs. time shows the current starts at 2A and exponentially decays to 0. What was the voltage of the source? (Hint: consider the initial state).

docs.title: 8. Capacitor Network
docs.text: Find the equivalent capacitance for a circuit where a \(10\,μ \text{F}\) capacitor is in series with a parallel combination of a \(5\,μ \text{F}\) capacitor and a \(20\,μ \text{F}\) capacitor.

docs.title: 9. Semiconductor Theory
docs.text: Describe the function of a semiconductor diode in a circuit. What is a "band gap" and how does it relate to conductivity?

docs.title: 10. Charge Storage
docs.text: How much charge is stored on a \(100\,μ\text{F}\) capacitor when it is connected to a 20 V source?

docs.title: 1. Propagation of Error (Product)
docs.text: The length and width of a rectangular plate are measured to be \(L = (15.3 \pm 0.1)\text{ cm}\) and \(W = (8.4 \pm 0.1)\text{ cm}\). Calculate the area of the plate and its absolute uncertainty.

docs.title: 2. Propagation of Error (Power)
docs.text: The radius of a sphere is measured to be \(r = (6.20 \pm 0.05)\text{ cm}\). Calculate the volume of the sphere and its associated uncertainty.

docs.title: 3. Statistics
docs.text: Ten measurements of the time period of a pendulum are (in seconds): 2.01, 1.99, 2.02, 2.00, 1.98, 2.01, 2.03, 1.99, 2.00, 2.02. Calculate the mean value and the standard deviation of these measurements.

docs.title: 4. Relative Uncertainty
docs.text: A car's speedometer has a 5% uncertainty. If it reads 60 km/h, what is the range of the car's actual speed?

docs.title: 5. Combined Uncertainty
docs.text: The resistance R is calculated using Ohm's Law, \(R = V/I\). If the voltage is measured as \(V = (10.0 \pm 0.2)\text{ V}\) and the current as \(I = (2.00 \pm 0.05)\text{ A}\), what is the calculated resistance and its uncertainty?

docs.title: 6. Error Analysis
docs.text: The mass of the Earth M can be estimated using the formula \(M = \frac{g R^2}{G}\). Calculate the percentage error in the mass of the Earth if the error in measuring g is 1% and the error in measuring R is 0.5%. (Assume G is known exactly).

docs.title: 7. Percentage Calculation
docs.text: A measurement of time is recorded as \(t = 5.45 \pm 0.22\) seconds. What is the percentage uncertainty of this measurement?

docs.title: 8. Instrument Precision
docs.text: A digital thermometer reads \(25.4^\circ\text{C}\). Assuming the uncertainty is half the value of the last digit, what is the absolute uncertainty of this measurement?

docs.title: 9. Standard Deviation
docs.text: Eleven students received the following scores on a test: 88, 92, 79, 85, 95, 81, 86, 90, 83, 77, 89. What is the standard deviation of these test scores?

docs.title: 10. Experimental Gravity
docs.text: An apple is dropped from a height of \(h = 10.0 \pm 0.1\) meters. The time it takes to fall is measured as \(t = 1.42 \pm 0.05\) seconds. Using the formula \(g = 2h/t^2\), calculate the acceleration due to gravity and its uncertainty from this experiment.

docs.title: 1. Density Comparison
docs.text: Instead of just stating the difference, calculate the average density of the Solar System (mass \(\approx M_{Sun}\), volume within Pluto's orbit \(\approx 40 \text{ AU}\)) versus the Milky Way galaxy (mass \(\approx 10^{12} M_{Sun}\), volume \(\approx\) disk \(100\text{kly} \times 1\text{kly}\)). Compare the orders of magnitude.

docs.title: 2. Galactic Geometry
docs.text: The Milky Way galaxy has a diameter of about 100,000 light-years and a thickness of about 1,000 light-years. What is the ratio of its diameter to its thickness?

docs.title: 3. Cosmic Timeline
docs.text: How long after the Big Bang did the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) radiation originate? What temperature did the universe cool to at that moment (approx.)?

docs.title: 4. Fermi Estimation
docs.text: The Milky Way contains approximately 200 billion stars. If these were distributed equally among Earth's 8 billion people, how many stars would each person get?

docs.title: 5. Space Travel Kinetics
docs.text: The minimum distance from Earth to Mars is about 55 million km. How long would it take a spacecraft traveling at a constant speed of 40,000 km/h to reach Mars?

docs.title: 6. Galactic Collision
docs.text: The Andromeda galaxy is about 2.5 million light-years away and is moving towards our Milky Way at about 110 km/s. Estimate how long it will be until the two galaxies collide.

docs.title: 7. Light Delay
docs.text: A message is sent from Earth to a probe orbiting Jupiter, which is 600 million km away. How long does the message take to arrive? (Use the speed of light, \(c \approx 3 \times 10^8 \text{ m/s}\)).

docs.title: 8. Astronomical Units
docs.text: What is an "Astronomical Unit" (AU)? Express the average distance from Earth to the Sun in kilometers and light-minutes.

docs.title: 9. Expansion Evidence
docs.text: What specific observation of distant galaxies (redshift) made by Edwin Hubble led to the conclusion that the universe is expanding?

docs.title: 10. Solar Light Time
docs.text: How long does it take for light from the Sun to reach Earth?

docs.title: 1. Scale Comparison
docs.text: How many times farther is the Sun from Earth compared to the Moon from Earth? (Sun-Earth distance \(\approx 150 \times 10^6\) km; Moon-Earth distance \(\approx 384,000\) km).

docs.title: 2. Angular Size
docs.text: Calculate the angular size (in degrees) of the Sun and the Moon as seen from Earth. Sun's diameter \(\approx 1.39 \times 10^6\) km; Moon's diameter \(\approx 3,474\) km. Why do they appear to be roughly the same size?

docs.title: 3. Rotational Velocity
docs.text: Calculate the linear speed (in km/s) of a point on the Earth's equator due to its rotation. Earth's radius \(\approx 6378\) km.

docs.title: 4. Orbital Mechanics
docs.text: Calculate the orbital speed of the International Space Station (ISS), which orbits at an altitude of approximately 400 km above the Earth's surface. (Earth's mass \(M_E \approx 5.97 \times 10^{24}\) kg).

docs.title: 5. Microgravity
docs.text: What is the acceleration due to gravity (\(g\)) at the altitude of the ISS (400 km)? Why do astronauts experience a state of "weightlessness" despite this gravity?

docs.title: 6. Geostationary Orbit
docs.text: Satellites in geostationary orbit remain above the same point on Earth. What must their orbital period be? Calculate the altitude of a geostation-ary orbit above the Earth's surface.

docs.title: 7. Escape Velocity
docs.text: What is the escape velocity from the surface of the Moon? (Moon's mass \(M_M \approx 7.35 \times 10^{22}\) kg; Moon's radius \(R_M \approx 1,737\) km).

docs.title: 8. Solar Gravity
docs.text: Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the Sun. By what factor would your weight increase if you could stand on its surface? (Sun's mass \(M_S \approx 2 \times 10^{30}\) kg; Sun's radius \(R_S \approx 6.96 \times 10^8\) m).

docs.title: 9. Stellar Density
docs.text: A white dwarf star has a mass roughly equal to the Sun's mass but a radius similar to the Earth's radius (~6371 km). What is the average density of such a white dwarf?

docs.title: 10. Megastructures
docs.text: A "Dyson Sphere" is a hypothetical megastructure that completely encompasses a star to capture its energy output. If the mass of Mercury (\(3.3 \times 10^{23}\) kg) were used to build a solar panel sphere with a surface density of 10 kg/m², what would be the radius of the sphere?

docs.title: 1. Cosmic Chronology
docs.text: Place the following events of the early universe in chronological order: Recombination (formation of neutral atoms), Big Bang Nucleosynthesis, Inflation, Formation of first galaxies, Quark-gluon plasma era.

docs.title: 2. Hubble's Law
docs.text: According to Hubble's Law (\(v = H_0 d\)), and using \(H_0 \approx 70 \text{ (km/s)/Mpc}\), at what distance would a galaxy be receding from us at the speed of light? This defines the approximate size of the observable universe.

docs.title: 3. Galactic Year
docs.text: Our Solar System orbits the center of the Milky Way (a distance of about 27,000 light-years) at a speed of about 220 km/s. How long does it take to complete one orbit (a "galactic year")?

docs.title: 4. Time Dilation
docs.text: A muon has an average lifetime of \(2.20\,\mu\text{s}\) in its own rest frame. If it travels at \(0.990c\), what will its average lifetime be as measured by an observer on Earth?

docs.title: 5. Length Contraction
docs.text: What speed must a 1-meter-long ruler have for its length to be observed as 0.5 meters due to length contraction?

docs.title: 6. Mass-Energy
docs.text: The "Little Boy" atomic bomb converted about 0.7 grams of mass into energy. Using \(E=mc^2\), calculate the energy released in Joules. (1 kiloton of TNT is approx. \(4.184 \times 10^{12}\) J).

docs.title: 7. Twin Paradox (Lite)
docs.text: An astronaut spends one year on the ISS, which travels at about 7.66 km/s. How much younger would the astronaut be than their twin on Earth due to time dilation?

docs.title: 8. Velocity Transformation
docs.text: A rocket traveling at \(0.8c\) away from Earth shoots a probe forward at \(0.5c\) relative to the rocket. What is the probe's speed as measured by an observer on Earth?

docs.title: 9. High Energy Physics
